original_data.question:
An 8-week-old male presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been breastfed since birth, and usually feeds for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about two weeks ago the patient began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds. She reports that he seems mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively. His height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles. On physical exam, the patient is cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her. He lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position. His abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?

model_response:
The patient’s symptoms are consistent with physiologic regurgitation, which is common in infants, especially those who are bottle-fed. The patient’s growth parameters are normal, suggesting adequate nutrition. The mother has already tried decreasing the volume of each feed, which has reduced the regurgitation frequency. Therefore, reassurance and counseling on positioning is the best next step in management. The patient should be kept upright for at least 30 minutes after feeds to minimize regurgitation. The mother should also be counseled that regurgitation is common in infants and is not necessarily a sign of pathologic gastroesophageal reflux.

###Suggested answers: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Female parents, human or animal.
A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.
The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The nursing of an infant at the breast.
A unit measure of time equal to 60 seconds.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Female parents, human or animal.
The off-white liquid secreted by the mammary glands of humans and other mammals. It contains proteins, sugar, lipids, vitamins, and minerals.
The creation of goods and services by a manufacturing process.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Of or relating to or providing nutrition.
Data elements that represent the clinical or administrative activities that a REMS program participant may be required to perform.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A part of the upper respiratory tract. It contains the organ of SMELL. The term includes the external nose, the nasal cavity, and the PARANASAL SINUSES.
The oval-shaped oral cavity located at the apex of the digestive tract and consisting of two parts: the vestibule and the oral cavity proper.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.

Flow in the opposite direction from normal, as the casting up of undigested food or gas from the stomach, or the backward flowing of blood into the heart, or between the chambers of the heart when a valve is incompetent.

A rare, slow growing, primary malignant tumor of the thyroid gland characterized by a lobulated architectural pattern and the presence of a biphasic cellular population composed of spindle epithelial cells and glandular cells. A small number of cases are composed exclusively of spindle epithelial cells or glandular cells.
The desire for FOOD generated by a sensation arising from the lack of food in the STOMACH.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Female parents, human or animal.
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.
Made less in size or amount or degree.

Flow in the opposite direction from normal, as the casting up of undigested food or gas from the stomach, or the backward flowing of blood into the heart, or between the chambers of the heart when a valve is incompetent.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
The passage of fresh blood from the anus. The blood is usually seen in the stools. The most common cause is lower gastrointestinal tract hemorrhage.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.
Gastrointestinal disturbances, skin eruptions, or shock due to allergic reactions to allergens in food.
A difficulty, disorder, or condition needing resolution.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.
Return to the normal structure and/or function, e.g. the subsidence of a pathologic process, as the subsidence of an inflammatory lesion or new growth.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
Any of the 99 numbered points that divide an ordered set of scores into 100 parts each of which contains one-hundredth of the total.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
Any of the 99 numbered points that divide an ordered set of scores into 100 parts each of which contains one-hundredth of the total.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Female parents, human or animal.

A procedure in which a laparoscope (LAPAROSCOPES) is inserted through a small incision near the navel to examine the abdominal and pelvic organs in the PERITONEAL CAVITY. If appropriate, biopsy or surgery can be performed during laparoscopy.
Concerning each of two or more things, especially those given or done in return. In mathematics, used to denote different kinds of mutual relation.

Mechanical devices designed for hoisting or lowering objects or persons from one place to another that is at a different height. Most specialized lifts in healthcare facilities and homes are used to transfer disabled persons and/or to permit them to overcome vertical barriers, typically limited to a difference of about 6 m (20 feet); some are used to get to and from motor vehicles.
The upper part of the human body, or the front or upper part of the body of an animal, typically separated from the rest of the body by a neck, and containing the brain, mouth, and sense organs.

Part of the body in humans and primates where the arms connect to the trunk. The shoulder has five joints; ACROMIOCLAVICULAR joint, CORACOCLAVICULAR joint, GLENOHUMERAL joint, scapulathoracic joint, and STERNOCLAVICULAR joint.
The posture of an individual lying face up.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively.
The condition of being dilated or stretched.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
